awd_titl_txt: I/UCRC GOALI Fundamental Research: Autonomous Self-Healing Sensor Network Radio and Mixed-Signal Readout System Design
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal seeks funding for the Center for Connection One-Communication Circuits and Systems Research studies conducted by the Arizona State University site (lead). Funding Requests for Fundamental Research are authorized by an NSF approved solicitation, NSF 10-507.  The solicitation invites I/UCRCs to submit proposals for support of industry-defined fundamental research. 
	
The focus of this proposal is on the development of reliable self-healing sensor network radio and mixed-signal analog/digital readout system design.  The chip is to be eventually fabricated. As a result of this work there would be models and software for system-level characterization of radio and mixed-signal readout chains along with hardware modules, software for system and circuit level compensation, and software for global decision making. The project takes a global view from the sensor interface to the RF domain for a reliable operation of the components. The PIs are well qualified for this work having experience in reliability radio transceiver design, system and circuit level test, and circuit calibration and compensation. Computer clusters and the Wireless Integrated Nanotechnology center at Arizona State University will be helpful for assembling integrated circuits and printed circuit boards.

Deployment of sensor networks into remote, hard-to-reach areas for data collection and analysis can have a profound impact to improve the lives of many. These systems hold great promise to increase capabilities in terms of predicting and preventing from impending dangers, such as radiation, air and drinking water pollution, and failures in infrastructure, such as highways and bridges. Successful outcomes of this research will enable the production of miniature and intelligent sensor systems with high yield, lower cost, and long lifetimes.   The proposed work is a continuation of the ongoing activities within the center, and as such it directly benefits the center for its lifetime.

por.por_cntn:
Sensor networks provide exciting opportunities to improve lives by providing continuous and effective solutions for safety monitoring, homeland security, battlefield exploration, environmental monitoring, and structural safety monitoring. Various challenges exist for the widespread proliferation of sensor networks. To enable deployment in large, hard-to-reach areas, sensor network nodes have to be manufactured in small form with low cost, consume very little power, and operate autonomously for an extended period. While various power-efficient methods for failure detection and tolerance have been developed for digital components, such techniques do not exist for analog and RF components. Since radio transceiver and mixed-signal readout chains constitute two of the fundamental building blocks for a sensor-node system, failure detection, diagnosis, and tolerance techniques are needed for these components in order to ensure reliable operation.

History is full of anecdotal evidence on how access to advanced technology can improve lives immensely. Deployment of sensor networks into remote, hard-to-reach areas for data collection and analysis can have a profound impact to improve the lives of many. These systems hold great promise to increase capabilities in terms of predicting and preventing from impending dangers, such as radiation, air and drinking water pollution, and failures in infrastructure, such as highways and bridges. In the past decade, various such sensor networks have been deployed in pilot programs, successfully collecting data. Most of the research work to date has focused on demonstrating the implementation and design concepts.

This research project focuses on developing a unified framework for on-chip performance characterization, monitoring, calibration, and adaptation of radio transceiver and mixed-signal readout chains of sensor networks. These issues are also becoming a major concern for chip manufacturers as integration levels increase and feature sizes scale down. To this end, this project involved extensive industry collaboration on testing, diagnosis, calibration, and reconfiguration of analog/RF circuits.

Specific outcomes for the benefit of the society include:

  • Development and dissemination of an aging simulation framework for analog and RF circuits: While tools for digital circuits exist to evaluate and predict the effect of aging, such tools are generally not applicable to analog circuits since analog circuits differ in terms of how they function. In this project, graduate students have developed a framework to enable this simulation. This simulator can be used both at design time to make improvements to the design to extend the lifetime or for in-field data extraction and statistical modeling.
  • Development of statistical tools to predict current state and remaining lifetime of analog and RF circuits: Techniques have been developed for the prediction of analog circuit lifetime from a specification perspective. These techniques can be used for two purposes: (a) estimating the point of failure for an analog device in deployment, and (b) estimating the age of a given device to prevent counterfeiting. 
  • Techniques to mitigate the effects of aging at design time: Design rules are supposed to guarantee a particular lifetime for the devices in a circuit. However, for analog circuits, performance degrades gradually after deployment and a parametric failure can happen long before a catastrophic failure in the underlying devices. Techniques have been developed to prevent premature failure in analog components at design time so as to guarantee a minimum lifetime from a performance perspective.
